name: Anicetus
comments: Was the leader of an unsuccessful anti-Roman uprising in Pontus in 69

name: Gannascus
comments: Deserted Cananefate soldier. Leading pirate raids of the Chauci into province Gallia Belgica (Belgium) between AD 41–47, when he was captured by the Romans.

name: Demetrius of Pharos
comments: His actions precipitated the Second Illyrian War.

name: Dionysius the Phocaean
comments: Phocaean admiral active against Carthaginian and Tyrsenian merchants in the years following the Greco–Persian Wars.

name: Gan Ning
comments: His party carried bells as their trademark to frighten the commoners.

name: Teuta of Illyria
comments: Queen regent, fostered the pirates among her people, and had a Roman diplomat killed by them.

name: Genthus of Illyria
comments: Was accused by the Romans of organizing and aiding pirate raids in Italy.

name: Glauketas
comments: Greek inscriptions of the Athenian navy raiding his base on Kynthnos Island and capturing him and his men, "making the sea safe for those that sailed thereon."

name: Sextus Pompeius
comments: He was the last focus of opposition to the Second Triumvirate.

name: Giorgio Adorno
comments: Knight of Malta active in the Mediterranean. Originally from Naples, he was elected "Captain-General of the Galleys" in 1547, 1549, 1557 and 1558.[2]

name: James Alday
comments: An English privateer. Raided Spanish ports with James Logan and William Cooke.

name: William Aleyn
comments: English pirate active in the Thames and English Channel. Associate of William Kyd.

name: Jean Ango
comments: A French ship-owner who provided ships to Francis I for exploration of the globe.

name: Aruj
comments: An Ottoman privateer and Bey (Governor) of Algiers and Beylerbey (Chief Governor) of the West Mediterranean.

name: Awilda
comments: She and some of her female friends dressed like sailors and commandeered a ship.

name: Hayreddin Barbarossa
comments: An Ottoman privateer and later Admiral who dominated the Mediterranean for decades.

name: Barnim VI, Duke of Pomerania
comments: A Pomeranian duke supporting privateers in the Baltic Sea region and later going on pirate raids himself.

name: Baldassare Cossa
comments: Antipope during the Western Schism, John XXIII was accused of—among other crimes—piracy, incest and sodomy.

name: John Crabbe
comments: Flemish pirate known for his successful use of a ship-mounted catapult. Once won the favor of Robert the Bruce and acted as a naval officer for England during the Hundred Years' War (after being captured by King Edward III.)

name: Pier Gerlofs Donia
comments: From Arum, Friesland. Known as Grutte Pier 'big Pier' because of his length. Another nickname was 'Cross of the Dutchmen'. A Frisian warrior, pirate, freedom fighter, folk hero and rebel. Mainly active with his band De Arumer Zwarte Hoop 'Arum's Black Heap' at the Zuyderzee, the Netherlands.

name: Erlend Eindridesson
comments: Norwegian nobleman, plundered German ships in the Sognefjord.

name: Eric of Pomerania
comments: The first king of the Nordic Kalmar Union, he spent his last years living on the island of Gothland and "sent forth piratical expeditions against friend and foe alike".[4]

name: Alv Erlingsson
comments: He was a favorite of the Queen, yet committed countless acts of piracy throughout his life

name: Eustace the Monk
comments: He was a mercenary for both England and France.

name: Jean Fleury
comments: French privateer and naval officer under Jean Ango. Seized three Spanish ships carrying Aztec treasure from Mexico to Spain in 1523.

name: Magnus Heinason
comments: Faroese naval hero and privateer. Was executed for piracy, though charges were later dropped.

name: Klein Henszlein
comments: A 16th-century pirate who raided shipping in the North Sea until his defeat and capture by a fleet from Hamburg

name: Wijerd Jelckama
comments: The nephew of Pier Gerlofs Donia (also known as Grutte Pier), fought along his side against the Saxon and Hollandic invaders.

name: William Kyd
comments: English pirate active in South West England during the early-to-mid-15th century.

name: Gödeke Michels
comments: A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former Victual Brothers (Vitalienbrüder)

name: Martin Pechlin
comments: Died in Mandal, Norway. One of the most feared pirates in his time

name: Didrik Pining
comments: A pirate and privateer operating in the North Sea. Often partnered with Hans Pothorst.

name: Hans Pothorst
comments: A pirate and privateer operating in the North Sea. Often partnered with Didrik Pining.

name: Salih Reis
comments: A Turkish privateer and Ottoman admiral.

name: Turgut Reis
comments: A Turkish privateer and Ottoman admiral as well as Bey of Algiers; Beylerbey of the Mediterranean; and first Bey later Pasha of Tripoli.

name: Klaus Störtebeker
comments: A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former Victual Brothers (Vitalienbrüder)

name: Yermak Timofeyevich
comments: A leader of a gang of river pirates, along the Don River region, of Russia and later, led an expedition, in the Russian conquest of Siberia, in the reign of Tsar Ivan the Terrible.

name: Kristoffer Trondson
comments: A Norwegian nobleman-turned pirate and privateer. Operated in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea. Gave up piracy in 1542 and eventually, became admiral of the Danish-Norwegian Fleet.

name: Bartholomeus Voet
comments: Second leader of Victual Brohers, plundered and burned down the Norwegian city Bergen in 1429

name: Hennig Wichmann
comments: A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former Victual Brothers (Vitalienbrüder)

name: Cord Widderich
comments: A pirate active during political conflicts between Dithmarschen and North Frisia in the early 15th century.

name: Magister Wigbold
comments: A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former Victual Brothers (Vitalienbrüder)

name: Wimund
comments: He was a bishop who became a seafaring warlord adventurer.

name: Uluj Ali
comments: An Italian-born Muslim corsair, who later became an Ottoman admiral and Chief Admiral (Kaptan-ı Derya) of the Ottoman Fleet in the 16th century.

name: Nicholas Alvel
comments: Active in the Ionian Sea.[citation needed]

name: Pedro Menéndez de Avilés
comments: A Spanish Admiral and pirate hunter, de Aviles is remembered for his destruction of the French settlement of Fort Caroline in 1565.

name: Samuel Axe
comments: An English privateer in Dutch service, Axe served with English forces in the Dutch Revolt against Habsburg rule.

name: Sir Andrew Barton
comments: Served under a Scottish letter of marque, but was described a pirate by English and Portuguese.

name: Abraham Blauvelt
comments: One of the last Dutch corsairs of the mid-17th century, Blauvelt mapped much of South America.

name: Jambe de Bois
comments: Known for his sacking of Santiago de Cuba in 1554

name: Jean Bontemps
comments: Active in the Caribbean Sea. He attacked Santa Marta, Cartagena de Indias, Rio de Hacha and Margarita island.

name: Jan de Bouff
comments: de Bouff served as a Dunkirker in Habsburg service during the Dutch Revolt.

name: Rock Brasiliano
comments: Pirate born in the town of Groningen, long residence of Dutch colony of Brasil. Active in the Caribbean and captain of pirates of Jamaica. Known for his fury and great cruelty and sadism, especially against Spaniards.[5]

name: Hendrik Brouwer
comments: Brouwer was a privateer who fought the Habsburgs during the Dutch revolt, holding the city of Castro, Chile hostage for a period of two months.[6]

name: Nathaniel Butler
comments: Despite a comparatively unsuccessful career as a privateer, Butler was later colonial governor of Bermuda.

name: John Callis
comments: Welsh pirate active along the southern coast of Wales.

name: Thomas Cavendish
comments: The first man to intentionally circumnavigate the globe, Cavendish also raided numerous Spanish towns and ships in the New World.[7][8][9][10][11]

name: Jacob Collaart
comments: A Flemish admiral who served as privateer and one of the Dunkirkers in Spanish Habsburg service during the Dutch Revolt, responsible for the destruction of at least 150 fishing boats.

name: Claes Compaan
comments: Former Dutch corsair and privateer, he later became a pirate and was successful in capturing hundreds of ships in Europe, the Barbary coast and West Africa.

name: Baltazar de Cordes
comments: A Dutch corsair who fought against the Spanish during the early 17th century.

name: Simon Danziker
comments: Dutch corsair and privateer who later became a Barbary corsair based in Algiers and Tunis during the early 17th century. He and John Ward dominated the Western Mediterranean during the early 17th century.

name: Sir Francis Drake
comments: Known as "el Draque" (the Dragon), he was an Elizabethan corsair who raided Spanish merchant shipping on behalf of Queen Elizabeth I.[12][13]

name: Peter Easton
comments: A privateer, then pirate, who was able to retire in Villefranche, Savoy with an estimated worth of two million pounds.

name: Jan Evertsen
comments: Dutch admiral and corsair.[citation needed]

name: Juan Garcia
comments: One of the Spanish privateers who accompanied Jan Jacobsen on his last voyage in 1622.

name: Sir Michael Geare
comments: Elizabethan Sea Dog active in the West Indies up until the turn of the 17th century.

name: Piers Griffith
comments: From 1600 to 1603, Griffith was active against Spanish shipping.[14]

name: Sir John Hawkins
comments: An Elizabethan corsair active off the coasts of West Africa and Venezuela. His work in ship design was important during the threat of invasion from the Spanish Armada.[15][16]

name: Piet Pieterszoon Hein
comments: After serving as a Spanish galley slave for four years, Hein later captured 11,509,524 guilders of cargo from the Spanish treasure fleet.

name: Moses Cohen Henriques
comments: Dutch pirate of Portuguese Sephardic Jewish origin active in the Caribbean against Spain and Brazil against Portugal

name: Richard Ingle
comments: Maryland privateer and pirate. In an extension of the English Civil War in the Catholic colony of Maryland he and the Puritan settlers raided ships belonging to Catholics and the colonial governor Lord Baltimore. Ingle seized control of the Maryland capital briefly and was later hanged for piracy.

name: Pieter Adriaanszoon Ita
comments: Dutch corsair and privateer. Commanded one of the earliest and largest expeditions against the Portugal and Spain in the Caribbean during 1628.

name: Jan Jacobsen
comments: Flemish-born privateer in English service during the Eighty Years' War.

name: Willem Jacobszoon
comments: Dutch corsair who accompanied Pieter Schouten on one of the first major expeditions to the West Indies.[citation needed]

name: Willem Jansen
comments: Dutch corsair based in Duinkerken and one time officer under Jacques Colaert.[citation needed]

name: Jan Janszoon
comments: Known also as Murad Reis, originally Dutch, he was a fighter in Morocco who converted to Islam after being captured by a Moorish state in 1618. He began serving as a Navy fighter, one of the most famous of the 17th-century "Salé Rovers"

name: Zheng Jing
comments: Chinese pirate and warlord. The eldest son of Koxinga and grandson of Zheng Zhilong, he succeeded his father as ruler of Tainan and briefly occupied Fujian.

name: Cornelius Jol
comments: Dutch corsair successful against the Spanish in the West Indies. One of the first to use a wooden peg leg.

name: Shirahama Kenki
comments: Japanese pirate and one of the first Japanese with whom the southern Vietnamese kingdom of the Nguyễn Lords made contact.

name: Lawrence Keymis
comments: Lawrence Keymis was a seaman and companion of Sir Walter Raleigh in his expeditions to Spanish colony of Guayana in 1595 and 1617 to search for England El Dorado (actual Venezuela).[17] In another expedition in 1596 led a force inland Guayana along the banks of the Essequibo River, reaching what he wrongly believed to be Lake Parime.[18]

name: Sir James Lancaster
comments: Elizabethan Sea Dog active in India during the late 16th century. Later a chief director for the East India Company.

name: Peter Love
comments: An English pirate who set up base in the Outer Hebrides and was active around Ireland and Scotland. He was betrayed by the outlaw Neil MacLeod and executed in 1610.

name: Hendrick Jacobszoon Lucifer
comments: Hendrick captured 1.2 million guilders from a Honduran treasure fleet, but was mortally wounded in the process.

name: Sir Henry Mainwaring
comments: English privateer and pirate hunter. His pirate fleet nearly broke the truce between England and Spain following the Anglo-Spanish War.

name: Arnaut Mami
comments: Active in the Narrow Sea (the modern day Adriatic Sea). He was the squadron admiral and the supreme commander of all Islamic vessels in North Africa and Pasha Algiers, known as the most formidable corsair of that period.

name: Jan Mendoza
comments: Plundered the water between Iceland and Norway, and the coast of Finnmark and Nordland. Hunted down and captured by Admiral Jørgen Daa and explorer Jens Munk by order of king Christian IV of Denmark-Norway. Mendoza was executed by hanging in Copenhagen. The king recovered 8 treasure chests of gold coins, each chest requerd 10 man to lift.

name: Olivier van Noort
comments: Despite his venture being of limited success, it was the inspiration that led to the formation of the Dutch East India Company.

name: Roger North
comments: Roger North was a seaman and companion of Sir Walter Raleigh in his expeditions to Spanish colony of Guayana in 1617 to search for England El Dorado (actual Venezuela).[17] North in 1619 petitioned for letters patent authorising him to establish the king's right to the coast and country adjoining the River Amazon; to found a plantation or settlement there, and to open a direct trade with the natives.

name: John Nutt
comments: An English pirate active in Newfoundland.

name: Grace O'Malley
comments: An important figure in Irish legend who is still present in popular culture today.[19][20]

name: John Oxenham
comments: Elizabethan Sea Dog and associate of Sir Frances Drake during the early years of the Anglo-Spanish War. First English privateer to enter the Pacific though Panama.[citation needed]

name: William Parker
comments: Elizabethan Sea Dog active in the West Indies. Successfully captured Porto Bello in 1602 without firing a shot.[citation needed]

name: Ali Pegelin
comments: Also known as Pisselingh, from Vlissingen (hence his name Pisselingh). Was for 40 years one of the most prominent pirates of Algiers. Settled in 1645 in Algiers with great fortune.[5]

name: Pedro de la Plesa
comments: He and Juan Garcia who joined Jan Jacobsen on his final voyage in 1622.

name: Sir Amyas Preston
comments: Elizabethan Sea Dog as part of expedition of Walter Raleigh in 1595 sacked Caracas and Coro with George Somers.

name: Sir Walter Raleigh
comments: Elizabethan corsair who commanded two expeditions to search for England the fabled "El Dorado" in the Spanish colony of Guayana (modern-day Venezuela).

name: Assan Reis
comments: Former Dutch privateer turned Barbary corsair. He attacked the Dutch ship St. Jan Babtista under Jacob Jacobsen of Ilpendam on March 7, 1626.[citation needed]

name: Murat Reis the Elder
comments: An Ottoman Albanian privateer and Ottoman admiral who took part in all of the early naval campaigns of Turgut Reis.

name: James Riskinner
comments: A lieutenant on the ship Warwick, then part of a fleet under the command of Nathaniel Butler, he later took part in a privateering expedition between May–September 1639.

name: Jean-François de La Rocque de Roberval
comments: French nobleman and adventurer who, through his friendship with King Francis, became the first Lieutenant General of New France. As a corsair he attacked towns and shipping throughout the Spanish Main, from Cuba to Colombia. He died in Paris as one of the first Huguenot martyrs.

name: Ben Robins
comments: English privateer in the English West Indies.

name: Isaac Rochussen
comments: A Dutch corsair active against the English during the Second and Third Anglo-Dutch War. His capture of The Falcon, an East India Company merchantman, was one of the most valuable prizes captured during the late-17th century.

name: Mahieu Romboutsen
comments: Dutch corsair in the service of Spain. Was part of a three ship squadron under Jacques Colaert and was captured with him after a five-hour battle with Jan Evertsen.[21][self-published source?]

name: William Rous
comments: Dutch corsair and privateer based on Providence Island. He was involved in privateering expeditions for the Providence Island Company and later commander of Fort Henry.

name: Jan van Ryen
comments: Dutch corsair active in the West Indies. Reportedly killed with a number of colonists attempting to establish one of the first colonies on the Wiapoco in Dutch Guiana.

name: Pieter Schouten
comments: Dutch corsair who led one of the Dutch expeditions to the West Indies.

name: Sir George Somers
comments: Elizabethan Sea Dog in 1595 sacked Caracas and Coro with Amyas Preston. Active in the West Indies up until the turn of the 17th century.

name: Jacques de Sores
comments: A French pirate whose sole documented act was his attack and burning of Havana in 1555.

name: Matsura Takanobu
comments: One of the most powerful feudal lords of Kyūshū and one of the first lords to allow trading with Europeans

name: Guillaume Le Testu
comments: French privateer, explorer and cartographer. First navigator to chart Australia in 1531.

name: Dirck Simonszoon van Uitgeest
comments: Dutch corsair who commanded a Dutch West India Company expedition to Brazil bringing back over 12 Portuguese and Spanish prizes.[citation needed]

name: De Veenboer
comments: De Veenboer meaning the Peat Bog Farmer. Former Dutch corsair and privateer. Later became a Barbary corsair under Simon the Dancer and eventually commanded the Algiers corsair fleet.[5]

name: Sir Francis Verney
comments: English nobleman who left behind his inheritance to become a Barbary corsair.

name: Johannes van Walbeeck
comments: Dutch admiral and corsair. Captured Curaçao in 1634 and later served as governor.

name: John Ward
comments: A notorious English pirate around the turn of the 17th century who later became a Barbary Corsair operating out of Tunis during the early 1600s.

name: Jacob Willekens
comments: Dutch admiral who led Dutch corsairs on the first major privateering expedition to the West Indies.

name: Cornelis Wittebol
comments: Dutch corsair in Spanish service. In February 1622, attacked a fishing fleet from the Veere and Maasmond sinking several ships and bringing back the survivors to ransom in Duinkerken.[citation needed]

name: Hendrik Worst
comments: Dutch corsair who accompanied Pieter Schouten in his expedition to the West Indies.[citation needed]

name: Wang Zhi
comments: One of the chief figures among the wokou of the 16th century.

name: Zheng Zhilong
comments: A convert to Christianity, Zhilon collaborated with Dutch forces, helping to create a monopoly on trade with Japan.

name: Filips van Zuylen
comments: Dutch corsair active against the Portuguese in West Africa.

name: Vincenzo Alessandri
comments: Originally a Knight of Malta, Alessandri was captured and enslaved.[citation needed]

name: Cornelius Andreson
comments: He is best known for attacking English traders off Acadia and for serving in King Philip's War.

name: Michiel Andrieszoon
comments: Dutch merchant-pirate. Associated with Thomas Paine and Laurens de Graff.[citation needed]

name: John Ansell
comments: Sailed with Henry Morgan and participated in his raids against Maracaibo and Gibraltar, Venezuela.

name: Jean Bart
comments: Born the son of a fisherman, Bart retired an admiral in French service.

name: Michel le Basque
comments: Pirate and flibustier (French buccaneer) from the Kingdom of Navarre in the southwest of France. He is best known as a companion of François L'Olonnais, with whom he sacked Maracaibo and Gibraltar.

name: John Bear
comments: English pirate active in the Caribbean who also served with the Spanish and French.

name: Philippe Bequel
comments: Was one of the first foreign privateers awarded a letter of marque by the governor of Jamaica

name: Jacob Janssen van den Bergh
comments: Dutch corsair and slave trader for the Dutch West India Company.[citation needed]

name: Charlotte de Berry
comments: A female pirate, she later commanded her own ship. Her story first appeared in 1836 and she may have been fictional.

name: Lancelot Blackburne
comments: Blackburne was an English clergyman, who became Archbishop of York, and – in popular belief – a pirate.

name: Eduardo Blomar
comments: Spanish renegade active in the Spanish Main during the 1670s. Tried in absentia and convicted of piracy with Bartolomé Charpes and Juan Guartem in Panama in 1679.[citation needed]

name: George Bond
comments: Active in the Caribbean, known for acting in league with the pirate-friendly Governor of St. Thomas, Adolph Esmit.

name: Pierre Bot
comments: French buccaneer active in the Caribbean.[citation needed]

name: Alexandre Bras-de-Fer
comments: A flibustier (French buccaneer) in the latter half of the mid-17th century. He is best known for capturing a Spanish ship after being shipwrecked, though his story is possibly apocryphal.

name: Nicolas Brigaut
comments: French pirate and buccaneer active in the Caribbean. He was closely associated with fellow corsair Michel de Grammont.

name: James Browne
comments: Scottish pirate and privateer active in the Caribbean. He is best known for his hasty execution and the effects it had on colonial Jamaican government.

name: Manuel Butiens
comments: Dutch renegade and Dunkirker in the service of Spain.[citation needed]

name: Jean du Casse
comments: Born to Huguenot parents, du Casse was allowed to join the French navy on the value of his prizes taken while a buccaneer.

name: Bartolomé Charpes
comments: Spanish renegade who was tried in absentia and convicted of piracy with Eduardo Blomar and Juan Guartem in Panama by Governor Don Dionicio Alceda in 1679.[citation needed]

name: Jean Charpin
comments: French pirate and buccaneer active in the Caribbean and off the coast of Africa. He is best known for sailing alongside Jean-Baptiste du Casse as well as for his Articles, or "Pirate Code."

name: Nicholas Clough
comments: Active in the Caribbean and off the coast of Africa. He is best remembered for leaving behind a well-documented Pirate Code, his "Articles of Agreement".

name: Edward Collier
comments: Served as Sir Henry Morgan's second-in-command throughout much of his expeditions against Spain during the mid-17th century.

name: Edmund Cooke
comments: Merchant captain, buccaneer, and pirate. He is best known for sailing against the Spanish alongside Bartholomew Sharp, John Coxon, Basil Ringrose, Lionel Wafer, and other famous buccaneers. Cooke's flag was red-and-yellow striped and featured a hand holding a sword.

name: John Cooke
comments: English buccaneer who led an expedition against the Spanish in the early 1680s.[citation needed]

name: John Cornelius
comments: Irish pirate supposedly active in the Red Sea and off the west coast of Africa. He succeeded William Lewis, who was killed after announcing he'd made a pact with the Devil. Lewis and Cornelius are likely the fictional creations of Captain Charles Johnson, who presented their stories among those of real historical pirates.

name: John Coxon
comments: One of the most famous of the Brethren of the Coast, a loose consortium of pirates and privateers who were active on the Spanish Main.

name: George Cusack
comments: Cruised both northern Europe and the West Indies, during and after the Anglo-Dutch Wars.

name: William Dampier
comments: Was the first person to circumnavigate the world three times.[22][23]

name: Edward Davis
comments: Led the last major buccaneer raid against Panama.

name: John Davis
comments: Davis was one of the earliest and most active buccaneers on Jamaica.

name: Jacquotte Delahaye
comments: Delahaye was a French Buccaneer, and together with Anne Dieu-Le-Veut was one of very few female buccaneers.

name: Edward Dempster
comments: A buccaneer and privateer active in the Caribbean. He is best known for his association with Henry Morgan.

name: Anne Dieu-Le-Veut
comments: Was originally one of the women – "Filles de Roi" – sent by the French government to Tortuga to become wives to the local male colonists.

name: Cornelius Essex
comments: An English buccaneer who took part in Captain Bartholomew Sharp's privateering expedition, the "Pacific Adventure", during the late 1670s.

name: Jacob Evertson
comments: He escaped Henry Morgan and sailed with Jan Willems for several years.

name: Alexandre Exquemelin
comments: A French writer, most known as the author of one of the most important sourcebooks of 17th century piracy, De Americaensche Zee-Roovers.

name: Jacob Fackman
comments: English buccaneer and pirate active in the Caribbean. He is best known for attacking the Spanish alongside Henry Morgan, John Morris, and David Marteen.

name: Jean Fantin
comments: French pirate active in the Caribbean and off the coast of Africa. He is best known for having his ship stolen by William Kidd and Robert Culliford.

name: Philip Fitzgerald
comments: Irish pirate and privateer who served the Spanish in the Caribbean.

name: Jean Foccard
comments: Associate of Laurens de Graaf and Michel de Grammont. He later joined them in their attack on Tampico in 1682.[citation needed]

name: Pierre Francois
comments: Mid-17th-century flibustier, or French buccaneer, active in the Caribbean. He is best known for a single attack on a Spanish pearl-diving fleet. His story appears only in Alexandre Exquemelin's History of the Buccaneers and the truth of his account is uncertain.

name: Thomas Freeman
comments: English buccaneer and pirate active in the Caribbean. He is best known for attacking the Spanish alongside Henry Morgan, David Marteen, and John Morris.

name: Louis Le Golif
comments: Known from his Memoirs; supposedly a real buccaneer active against the Spanish, Golif's Memoirs were a forgery and he is now assumed to be entirely fictional.

name: Laurens de Graaf
comments: Also known as Lorencillo and active in the Caribbean. Characterised as "a great and mischievous pirate" by Henry Morgan, de Graaf was a Dutch pirate, mercenary, and naval officer in the service of the French colony of Saint-Domingue. Sacked Veracruz. His companion was pirate Nicholas van Hoorn.[5]

name: John Graham
comments: English pirate active off New England and the African coast. May have been a doctor as well.

name: Michel de Grammont
comments: A French buccaneer, de Grammont primarily attacked Spanish holdings in Maracaibo, Gibraltar, Trujillo, La Guaira, Puerto Cabello, Cumana and Veracruz

name: Pierre le Grand
comments: Known only for a single attack against a Spanish galleon, his existence is disputed.

name: "Red Legs" Greaves
comments: Greaves's nickname was based on a commonly used term for reddened legs often seen among the Scottish and Irish who took to wearing kilts in almost any weather. Noted for his raid of Margarita Island. He may have been fictional; his story first appeared in 1924.

name: Francois Grogniet
comments: French buccaneer and pirate active against the Pacific coast of Spanish Central America.

name: Juan Guartem
comments: A Spanish renegade pirate who raided Spanish settlements in New Spain during the late 17th century with his most notable raid being against Chepo in 1679.

name: Jean Hamlin
comments: French buccaneer active in the Caribbean and off the coast of Africa. He was often associated with St. Thomas' pirate-friendly Governor Adolph Esmit.

name: Peter Harris
comments: English buccaneer and member of Captain Bartholomew Sharp's "Pacific Expedition". Killed at Panama in 1680.[citation needed]

name: Richard Hawkins
comments: A buccaneer and explorer who was later knighted.

name: Thomas Hawkins
comments: Pirate briefly active off New England. He was known for sailing with Thomas Pound.

name: Thomas Henley
comments: A pirate and privateer active in the Red Sea and the Caribbean.

name: Henry Holloway
comments: A pirate active off the American east coast, from South Carolina to Maine. Aided by a member of Governor James Colleton's Grand Council.

name: Nicholas  van Hoorn
comments: Merchant, privateer and later pirate, van Hoorn was hugely successful before dying of wound infection. Active in the Caribbean and based at the island Hispaniola. Sacked in 1683 Veracruz. Worked together with Laurens de Graaf aka Lorencillo.[5]

name: William Jackson
comments: It was the fleet under his command that captured Jamaica for England.

name: Bartholomeus de Jager
comments: Dutch corsair active against the Portuguese. He attacked a small merchant fleet at Fernando de Noronha capturing one merchant ship and driving off the other.[citation needed]

name: Daniel Johnson
comments: Became known as "Johnson the Terror" among the Spanish.

name: William Knight
comments: Along with Edward Davis, he took part in the final large buccaneer attack on Spanish holdings.

name: Jean L’Escuyer
comments: French pirate active on the Pacific coast of Central America. He sailed and fought alongside a number of prominent buccaneers such as Edward Davis, Francois Grogniet, William Dampier, and others.

name: François l'Olonnais
comments: Nicknamed "The Bane of Spaniards" (French: Fléau des Espagnols). l'Ollonais had a reputation for brutality, offering no quarter to Spanish prisoners. Famous by his raids against Maracaibo and Gibraltar, Venezuela.

name: Jelles de Lecat
comments: Sacked Spanish territories alongside Brasiliano, Reyning, Bradley, and Morgan. Often called "Yellahs," "Yallahs," or "Captain Yellows."

name: William Lewis
comments: Pirate supposedly active in the Caribbean, off the American east coast, and the west coast of Africa. He was known for sparing his victims, and for being killed after announcing he had made a pact with the Devil. He is likely the fictional creation of Captain Charles Johnson, who presented his story among those of real historical pirates.

name: Raveneau de Lussan
comments: An impoverished nobleman. Attacked targets in Central America. Known for a "long march" in 1688.

name: Thomas Magott
comments: English buccaneer who sailed with Bartholomew Sharp and others on the "Pacific Adventure".[citation needed]

name: Marquis de Maintenon
comments: A French nobleman who became a buccaneer in the Caribbean, selling his castle and title to Madame de Maintenon. Remarkable his raid of Margarita Island.

name: Edward Mansvelt / Mansfield
comments: Dutch buccaneer in English service. Known as the Admiral of the "Brethren of the Coast", Mansvelt was a mentor to Sir Henry Morgan who succeeded him following his death.

name: David Marteen
comments: Known primarily as the sole non-English Captain who participated in the raids against Spanish strongholds in present-day Mexico and Nicaragua.

name: Montbars the Exterminator
comments: A former French naval officer and gentleman adventurer, he engaged in a violent and destructive war against Spain in the Caribbean and the Spanish Main. His hatred of the Spanish earned him the name "Montbars the Exterminator".

name: Sir Henry Morgan
comments: A privateer who later retired to become Lieutenant Governor of Jamaica.[24][25] he participated in his raids against Panama, Maracaibo, Gibraltar, Porto Bello.

name: John Morris
comments: A skilled pilot, he served with both Christopher Myngs and Henry Morgan before becoming a pirate hunter.

name: Sir Christopher Myngs
comments: Described as "unhinged and out of tune" by the governor of Jamaica, Myngs nevertheless became a Vice-Admiral of the Blue in the Royal Navy. In 1658, raided the coast of South-America; failing to capture a Spanish treasure fleet, he destroyed Tolú and Santa Marta in present-day Colombia instead. In 1659, he plundered Cumaná, Puerto Cabello and Coro in present-day Venezuela.

name: Thomas Paine
comments: A colonial American privateer who raided several settlements in the West Indies with Jan Willems, most notably against Rio de la Hacha in 1680. He also drove the French from Block Island.

name: Manuel Ribeiro Pardal
comments: Portuguese privateer in the service of Spain. One of the few successful privateers active against the buccaneers of the Caribbean during the late 17th century.

name: George Peterson
comments: Part of his crew consisted of the remnants of the crews of Jean Hamlin and two recently deceased pirates, Jan "Yankey" Willems and Jacob Evertson.

name: Pierre Le Picard
comments: An officer under l'Ollonais and Henry Morgan, he and Moise Vauquelin left to pursue a career on their own. He later served in King William's War. He may have been one of the first buccaneers to raid shipping on both the Caribbean and Pacific coasts.

name: Chevalier du Plessis
comments: French privateer active in the West Indies. He was succeeded by Moise Vauquelin following his death.[citation needed]

name: Baron Jean de Pointis
comments: His greatest venture was the 1697 Raid of Cartagena.

name: Bartolomeu Português
comments: One of the earliest pirates to use a pirate code.

name: Thomas Pound
comments: Briefly commanded a small ship near Massachusetts before being captured.

name: Lawrence Prince
comments: Dutch buccaneer in English service. An officer under Sir Henry Morgan, he and John Morris led the vanguard at Panama in 1671.

name: Philip Ras
comments: Captured several English ships as both a corsair and privateer during the First Anglo-Dutch War.[citation needed]

name: Stenka Razin
comments: A Cossack pirate who operated on the Volga and later expanded into the Caspian Sea.

name: Peter Roderigo
comments: He is best known for attacking English traders off Acadia and for serving in King Philip's War.

name: Richard Sawkins
comments: Participated, along with John Coxon and Bartholomew Sharp, in the surprise attack on Santa Maria in Panama.

name: Lewis Scot
comments: Known for his attack on the city of Campeche, on the Yucatan Peninsula.

name: Robert Searle
comments: Jamaican-based buccaneer known for his sacks of Tobago and St. Augustine, Florida and occasional compatriot of Henry Morgan.

name: Bartholomew Sharp
comments: Plundered 25 Spanish ships and numerous small towns.

name: Gustav Skytte
comments: Attacked ships in the Baltic Sea, along with other accomplices of noble descent.

name: Bernard Claesen Speirdyke
comments: Dutch buccaneer active in the Caribbean, he was captured by Captain Manuel Ribeiro Pardal near Cuba and later executed.

name: Charles Swan
comments: A reluctant pirate, he begged for a pardon even as he looted his way around South America.

name: Jacques Tavernier / Le Lyonnais
comments: French buccaneer who took part in expeditions with Laurens de Graaf, Michel de Grammont, Pierre Le Grand, François l'Ollonais and Sir Henry Morgan before his execution in 1673. His existence is disputed as the only pre-20th century reference to him appears in Appleton's Cyclopedia of American Biography.[26][27]

name: Moïse Vauquelin / Moses Vanclein
comments: An officer under l'Ollonais, he also had a partnership with Pierre le Picard. In his later years, he wrote a book detailing the coastline of Honduras and the Yucatan along with fellow buccaneer Philippe Bequel.

name: Captain Veale
comments: Attacked ships along New England from Virginia to Boston with pirate John Graham.

name: Thomas Veale
comments: Known for legends of his buried treasure.

name: Cornelis Janszoon van de Velde
comments: Dutch corsair active near the Antillen, he was briefly associated with Bartholomeus de Jager.[citation needed]

name: Lionel Wafer
comments: An explorer whose work helped inspire the Darien Scheme.

name: Janke / Yankey Willems
comments: Dutch buccaneer active in the Caribbean.

name: Francis Witherborn
comments: English buccaneer, privateer, and pirate active in the Caribbean. He is best known for his brief association with Henry Morgan.

name: Thomas Woolerly
comments: A pirate and privateer active in the Caribbean and the Indian Ocean.

name: William Wright
comments: Despite being English, Wright was active as a privateer under a French commission. He later became a buccaneer.

name: James Allison
comments: Active near Cape Verde and the Bay of Campeche. Almost the entire record of Allison's piracy comes from trial records of a single incident, the seizure of the merchantman Good Hope.

name: Thomas Anstis
comments: Was mainly active in the Caribbean, and served under first Howell Davis and later Bartholomew Roberts.[26][29]

name: Leigh Ashworth
comments: A pirate and privateer operating in the Caribbean in the early 1700s.

name: John Auger
comments: Active in the Bahamas around 1718. He is primarily remembered for being captured by pirate turned pirate-hunter Benjamin Hornigold.

name: Adam Baldridge
comments: English pirate and one of the early founders of the pirate settlements in Madagascar.

name: Jonathan Barnet
comments: English privateer active in the Caribbean. He is best known for capturing pirates Calico Jack, Anne Bonney, and Mary Read.

name: Thomas Barrow
comments: Pirate active in the Caribbean. He is best known for proclaiming himself Governor of New Providence.

name: Don Benito
comments: Real name possibly Benito Socarras Y Aguero, he was a Spanish pirate and guarda costa privateer active in the Caribbean.

name: Charles Bellamy
comments: English pirate who raided colonial American shipping in New England and later off the coast of Canada. He is often confused with the more well-known Samuel "Black Sam" Bellamy, as they operated in the same areas at the same time.

name: Samuel Bellamy (Black Sam)
comments: Despite having a career of only 16 months, Bellamy was extraordinarily successful, capturing more than 50 ships before his death at age 28.[29]  His acquired wealth of five tons of treasure from his short career is speculated at US$120 million in 2008 dollars.[30] Bellamy began his pirate career under the command of Henry Jennings, a Buccaneer that turned pirate; but double-crossing Jennings, Bellamy fled to the Bahamas and joined Jennings' nemesis, Benjamin Hornigold of the Mary Anne. But quickly growing wearisome of Hornigold's refusal to attack English ships, Bellamy called for a vote of no confidence, and the crew ousted Hornigold and Blackbeard by a majority vote, electing Bellamy as captain. Bellamy's prize flagship, Whydah Galley, discovered by underwater explorer Barry Clifford in 1984, is currently the world's only fully authenticated Golden Age pirate shipwreck ever found.

name: Blackbeard (Edward Teach)
comments: With his fearsome appearance, Blackbeard is often credited with the creation of the stereotypical image of a pirate. Although his real name remains unknown, he began his pirate career as the first officer of Buccaneer-turned-pirate Captain Benjamin Hornigold of the Mary Anne. When a young crewman, Samuel Bellamy, called for a vote of no confidence in Hornigold for his refusal to attack English ships, the crew by a vote ousted Hornigold and Blackbeard, leaving the Mary Anne to Bellamy whom the crew elected their new captain.[26][29] His legend solidified after he took command of the Queen Anne's Revenge.[31]

name: Black Caesar
comments: A captured slave turned pirate, Black Caesar was a well-known pirate active off the Florida Keys during the early 18th century. He later acted as a lieutenant to Blackbeard and was one of five Africans serving on his flagship.[29]

name: Augustin Blanco
comments: He was noted for attacking in open boats, and for having a mixed-race crew.

name: Richard Bobbington
comments: Active in the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, and Persian Gulf. Sailed with Thomas Tew's crew after Tew's death. One of several captains of the Charming Mary.

name: Jean Bonadvis
comments: He is best known for his involvement with Benjamin Hornigold and "Calico Jack" Rackham.

name: Stede Bonnet
comments: Nicknamed "The Gentleman Pirate", Bonnet was born into a wealthy family before turning to piracy.[26][29]

name: Anne Bonny
comments: Despite never commanding a ship herself, Anne Bonny is remembered as one of few known female pirates.[26][29][32]

name: George Booth
comments: One of the earliest pirates active in the Indian Ocean and Red Sea.

name: John Bowen
comments: Was active in the Indian Ocean, his contemporaries included George Booth and Nathaniel North.

name: Joseph Bradish
comments: A pirate best known for a single incident involving a mutiny.

name: John Breholt
comments: Pirate and salvager active in the Caribbean, the Carolinas, and the Azores. He is best known for organizing several attempts to get the pirates of Madagascar to accept a pardon and bring their wealth home to England.

name: Nicholas Brown
comments: Active off the coast of Jamaica, Brown was eventually killed – and his head pickled – by childhood friend John Drudge.

name: Phineas Bunce
comments: Pirate active in the Caribbean. He was pardoned for piracy but reverted to it immediately afterwards and was killed by a Spanish pirate hunter.

name: Nathaniel Burches
comments: A privateer who operated out of New England. He was known for sailing alongside Regnier Tongrelow and Thomas Penniston, and for single-handedly defeating a huge Spanish ship.

name: Josiah ("Thomas") Burgess
comments: He is best known as one of the heads of New Providence's "Flying Gang."

name: Samuel Burgess
comments: Member of Captain William Kidd's crew in 1690 when the Blessed William was seized by Robert Culliford and some of the crew.

name: William Burke
comments: Pirate and trader active in the Caribbean and near Newfoundland, best known for aiding William Kidd.

name: James Carnegie
comments: Sailed in consort with Henry Jennings.

name: Canoot
comments: French pirate active off the coast of New England.

name: Dirk Chivers
comments: Active in the Red Sea and Indian Ocean, Chivers later retired from piracy and returned to the Netherlands.[26]

name: Adrian Claver
comments: A Dutch privateer based out of New England. He sailed alongside other prominent privateers such as John Halsey, Regnier Tongrelow, and Thomas Penniston.

name: Edward Coates
comments: A colonial American privateer in English service during the King William's War and later a pirate operating in the Red Sea and Indian Ocean during the mid-1690s.

name: Thomas Cocklyn
comments: Primarily known for his association with Howell Davis and Oliver La Buze, Cocklyn's activities after 1719 are unknown.[26][29]

name: John Cockram
comments: Pirate, trader, and pirate hunter in the Caribbean, best known for his association with Benjamin Hornigold.

name: John Cole
comments: Associated with Richard Worley and William Moody. He is known more for the unusual cargo of his pirate ship than for his piracy.

name: Robert Colley
comments: An American pirate active near Newfoundland and the Indian Ocean.

name: Thomas Collins
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean. He is best known for leading a pirate settlement and trading post on Madagascar.

name: Christopher Condent
comments: After entering into piracy in 1718, Condent later took a prize of £150,000 with his ship Fiery Dragon and retired to France, becoming a wealthy merchant.[26] Known by many names, including Condent, Congdon, Connor or Condell; and by given names including William, Christopher, Edmond or John.

name: Joseph Cooper
comments: Active in the Caribbean and the American east coast. He was best known for sailing alongside Francis Spriggs, and for the manner of his death.

name: William Coward
comments: A minor pirate active off the coast of Massachusetts. He is known for a single incident involving the seizure of one small vessel, largely thanks to events surrounding his trial.

name: Captain Crapo
comments: French privateer active in the Caribbean and off the American east coast during the War of Spanish Succession. He was highly successful, capturing a large number of English vessels which he sent back to his home ports in Martinique and Port Royal.

name: Mary Critchett
comments: She is best known for being one of only four female pirates from the Golden Age of Piracy.

name: Robert Culliford
comments: The former first mate of William Kidd, Culliford led a first mutiny against Kidd, stealing his ship Blessed William.[26][29]

name: Alexander Dalzeel
comments: Served under Henry Every. Was captured four times before finally being hanged.

name: Howell Davis
comments: Having a career that lasted only 11 months, Davis was ambushed during an attempt to kidnap the governor of Príncipe.[26][29]

name: Captain Davy
comments: French privateer active off New England during Queen Anne's War. He is best known for repeatedly evading capture by rival English and Dutch privateers such as Adrian Claver and Thomas Penniston.

name: Thomas Day
comments: Pirate and privateer active off the American east coast. He is known for being one cause of increasing tensions between the Governors of Maryland and Pennsylvania.

name: Robert Deal
comments: He is best known for his association with Charles Vane.

name: Nicholas de Concepcion
comments: Pirate active off the New England coast. An escaped slave, he was one of the few black or mulatto pirate captains.

name: Mathurin Desmarestz
comments: French pirate and buccaneer active in the Caribbean, the Pacific, and the Indian Ocean.

name: Etienne de Montauban
comments: French flibustier (buccaneer), privateer, and pirate active in the Caribbean and off the west African coast. Frequently referred to as Sieur de Montauban (last name occasionally Montauband), he wrote an account of his later voyages including surviving a shipwreck.

name: Francis Demont
comments: Pirate active in the Caribbean. His trial was important in establishing Admiralty law in South Carolina.

name: John Derdrake
comments: Known as "Jack of the Baltic." Danish pirate active in the 1700s. His story, if true, makes him one of the few pirates known to force his victims walk the plank.

name: George Dew
comments: He once sailed alongside William Kidd and Thomas Tew, and his career took him from Newfoundland to the Caribbean to the coast of Africa.

name: Edward England
comments: Differing from many other pirates of his day, England did not kill captives unless necessary.[26][29]

name: John Evans
comments: After an unsuccessful career as a legitimate sailor, Evans turned to piracy – initially raiding houses from a small canoe.

name: Henry Every (Avery)
comments: Famous as one of the few pirates of the era who was able to retire with his takings without being either arrested or killed in battle.[26]

name: Joseph Faro
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean. He is best known for sailing alongside Thomas Tew to join Henry Every's pirate fleet which captured and looted the fabulously rich Mughal ship Gunsway.

name: John Fenn
comments: Sailed with Bartholomew Roberts and, later, Thomas Anstis.

name: Lewis Ferdinando
comments: Active near Bermuda during the Golden Age of Piracy.

name: Francis Fernando
comments: Jamaican pirate and privateer active in the Caribbean. He was one of the few confirmed mixed-race Captains in the Golden Age of Piracy.

name: James Fife
comments: Active in the Caribbean. Murdered by forced men on his crew.

name: William Fly
comments: Raided off the New England coast before being captured and hanged at Boston, Massachusetts.

name: William Fox
comments: Pirate active in the Caribbean and off the African coast. He was indirectly associated with a number of more prominent pirates such as Bartholomew Roberts, Edward England, and Richard Taylor.

name: Richard Frowd
comments: He is best known for sailing with William Moody. He was one of a number of pirates to have both white and black sailors in his crew.

name: Ingela Gathenhielm
comments: Widow of Lars Gathenhielm, active on the Baltic Sea.

name: Lars Gathenhielm
comments: Active on the Baltic Sea

name: Captain Gincks
comments: A privateer based in New York. He is best known for sailing alongside Adrian Claver, and for a violent incident involving his sailors while ashore.

name: Richard Glover
comments: A pirate and slave-trader active in the Caribbean and the Red Sea in the late 1690s.

name: Robert Glover
comments: An Irish-American pirate active in the Red Sea area in the late 1690s.

name: Christopher Goffe
comments: A pirate and privateer active in the Red Sea and the Caribbean. He was eventually trusted to hunt down his former comrades.

name: John Golden
comments: A Jacobite pirate and privateer active in the waters near England and France. His trial was important in establishing Admiralty law, differentiating between privateers and pirates, and ending the naval ambitions of the deposed James II.

name: Thomas Goldsmith
comments: Chiefly remembered not for his piracy but for retiring and dying peacefully in his bed, and for his gravestone inscription.

name: Thomas Griffin
comments: A pirate and privateer active off New England. He is known for his association with George Dew.

name: Captain Grinnaway
comments: A pirate from Bermuda, best known for being briefly and indirectly involved with Edward Teach (or Thatch, alias Blackbeard).

name: Nathaniel Grubing
comments: English pirate who sailed in service to the French. He is best known for leading several raids on Jamaica before his capture.

name: Jean Baptiste Guedry
comments: Took over a small ship off Acadia and was tried for piracy. The trial was publicized to Indians as an example of English law.

name: Charles Harris
comments: He is best known for his association with George Lowther and Edward Low.

name: John Halsey
comments: Active in the Atlantic and Indian oceans, Halsey is remembered by Defoe as "brave in his Person, courteous to all his Prisoners, lived beloved, and died regretted by his own People."[26]

name: Israel Hands
comments: Also known as Basilica Hands.[33]  He is best known for being second in command to Edward Teach, better known as Blackbeard. Hands' first historical mention was in 1718, when Blackbeard gave him command of David Herriot's ship Adventure after Herriot was captured by Teach in March 1718.[31]

name: Don Miguel Enríquez (Henríquez)
comments: Although born a shoemaker, Enríquez was later awarded a letter of marque by Spain, going on to become knighted and gathering a fortune of over 500,000 pieces of eight.[28] Considered the "most accomplished" of the Hispanic privateers.[34]

name: David Herriot
comments: Captain of the Jamaican sloop Adventure, captured by Edward Teach, alias Blackbeard, in 1718. He joined Blackbeard's crew, and later when Stede Bonnet separated from Blackbeard, Herriott became his sailing master.  During the Battle of Cape Fear River Herriott was taken by Col. Rhet, of the sloop Royal James, on September 27, 1718.[35]  Herriott and boatswain, Ignatius Pell, turned King's evidence at their trial but escaped their Charleston prison on October 25. Herriott was shot and killed on Sullivan Island a few days later.[31]

name: John Hoar
comments: A pirate and privateer active in the late 1690s in the Red Sea area.

name: Benjamin Hornigold
comments: Known for being less aggressive than other pirates, Hornigold once captured a ship for the sole purpose of seizing the crew's hats.[26][29]

name: Thomas Howard
comments: Howard served under both George Booth and John Bowen and later commanded the Prosperous.

name: Samuel Inless
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean, best known for serving as Captain over Nathaniel North and George Booth.

name: John Ireland
comments: A pirate active in the Indian Ocean. He is best known for sailing with Thomas Tew. One of several captains of the Charming Mary.

name: John James
comments: A Welsh pirate active near Madagascar, Nassau, and the American east coast.

name: Henry Jennings
comments: Jennings was a later governor of the pirate haven of New Providence.[26] Although the Governor of Jamaica personally commissioned Jennings' privateering in 1715,[36] after Jennings' began attacking salvage camps and Spanish, English and French vessels,[37] Jennings was declared a pirate in April 1716.[38] Jennings and his fleet of pirates and privateers subsequently moved to Nassau.[38] Jennings was one of 400 pirates who took advantage of the British amnesty in 1718, and afterwards retired to Bermuda to live the rest of his life "as a wealthy, respected member of society."[39]

name: Henry Johnson
comments: Irish pirate active in the Caribbean. He shared captaincy with a Spaniard, Pedro Poleas. Johnson was best known thanks to an autobiography written by a sailor he captured and marooned.

name: Evan Jones
comments: Welsh-born pirate from New York active in the Indian Ocean, best known for his indirect connection to Robert Culliford and for capturing a future Mayor of New York.

name: John Julian
comments: Recorded as the first black pirate to operate in the New World.[29]

name: James Kelly (James Gilliam)
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean, Kelly was a long-time associate of William Kidd.

name: William "Captain" Kidd
comments: Although modern historians dispute the legitimacy of his trial and execution, the rumor of Captain Kidd's buried treasure has served only to build a legend around the man as a great pirate.  His property was claimed by the crown and given to the Royal Hospital, Greenwich, by Queen Anne.[26][29][40][41][42][43]

name: Henry King
comments: He is best known for attacking the slave ship John Hopewell, whose captured crew turned the tables and took his ship from him.

name: John King
comments: Although not ever a captain, King joined the crew of Sam Bellamy when they boarded the ship he was on, and is one of the youngest known pirates on record. His age is disputed at anywhere from 8–11 years.

name: Montigny la Palisse
comments: Sailed in consort with Bartholomew Roberts.

name: Robert Lane
comments: Was given command of a prize ship by Edward England, which was lost off Brazil with all hands.

name: Thomas Larimore
comments: Active in the Caribbean and off the eastern seaboard of the American colonies. After helping suppress Bacon's Rebellion and serving as a militia leader he turned to piracy, operating alongside John Quelch.

name: Peter Lawrence
comments: Dutch pirate and privateer active off New England and Newfoundland, and in the Caribbean. His and other pirates' dealings with Rhode Island's governors nearly led to the colony losing its charter.

name: John Leadstone / "Old Captain Crackers"
comments: A pirate and slave trader active off the west coast of Africa. Often called "Captain Crackers" or "Old Captain Cracker," he is best known for his actions against the English Royal African Company and for his brief involvement with Bartholomew Roberts.

name: Francois Le Sage
comments: Pirate and buccaneer active in the Caribbean and off the coast of Africa. He is primarily associated with fellow buccaneers Michiel Andrieszoon and Laurens de Graaf.

name: Francis Leslie
comments: He is best known as one of the leaders of the "Flying Gang" of pirates operating out of New Providence.

name: Olivier Levasseur (Oliver La Buse)
comments: Nicknamed "la Buse" (the Buzzard) for the speed with which he attacked his targets, Levasseur left behind a cryptic message that has yet to be deciphered fully today.[26][29]

name: Samuel Liddell
comments: A pirate, privateer, and merchant active in the Caribbean. He is best known for sailing alongside Henry Jennings.

name: Edward "Ned" Low
comments: A pirate known for his vicious torture, his methods were described as having "done credit to the ingenuity of the Spanish Inquisition in its darkest days".[26][29]

name: George Lowther
comments: Active in the Caribbean and the Atlantic, one of Lowther's lieutenants included Edward Low.[26][29]

name: Matthew Luke (Matteo Luca)
comments: A pirate and Spanish Guarda Costa active in the Caribbean.

name: Philip Lyne
comments: Known for his cruelty and his association with Francis Spriggs.

name: John Martel
comments: English pirate active in the Caribbean.

name: Simon Mascarino
comments: A Portuguese pirate active in the Caribbean. He was also a privateer in service of the Spanish.

name: William May
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean. He was best known for taking over William Kidd's ship Blessed William and sailing with Henry Every.

name: Edward Miller
comments: English pirate active in the Caribbean.

name: Christopher Moody
comments: Active off North and South Carolina, Moody offered no quarter to captured crews, signified by his flying of a red standard.[29] Often conflated with William Moody.

name: William Moody
comments: He is best known for his association with Olivier Levasseur and Thomas Cocklyn, crewmembers who succeeded him as Captains in their own right. Often conflated with Christopher Moody.

name: Captain Napin
comments: A pirate active in the Caribbean and off the American east coast. He is best known for sailing alongside Benjamin Hornigold.

name: Thomas Nichols
comments: A pirate active in the Caribbean and off the American east coast. He is best known as a leader among the "Flying Gang" of pirates operating out of New Providence.

name: Richard Noland
comments: He was best known for sailing with Samuel Bellamy before working for the Spanish.

name: John Norcross
comments: English Jacobite pirate and privateer who sailed in service to Sweden.

name: Nathaniel North
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean and Red Sea, North served with other famous contemporaries, including John Bowen and George Booth.

name: Amaro Pargo
comments: He was one of the most famous pirates of the golden age of piracy, and one of the most important personalities of the 18th century of Spain.

name: Major Penner
comments: Pirate captain active in the Caribbean. Kept his title of "Major" instead of "Captain."

name: Thomas Penniston
comments: A privateer who operated out of New England. He was known for sailing alongside Adrian Claver and Regnier Tongrelow.

name: James Plantain
comments: Plantain ruled the island of Madagascar between 1725 and 1728, primarily through fear, and was known as the "King of Ranter Bay".[26]

name: Daniel Porter
comments: Pirate and trader active in the Caribbean. He is best known for his associations with Benjamin Hornigold and Bartholomew Roberts.

name: John Prie
comments: A mutineer and minor pirate in the Caribbean.

name: John Pro
comments: Best known for leading a pirate trading post near Madagascar.

name: John Quelch
comments: Quelch was the first person tried for piracy outside England under Admiralty Law and therefore without a jury.

name: "Calico Jack" John Rackham
comments: Earned his nickname for the colourful calico clothes that he wore.[26][29]

name: George Raynor
comments: Active in the Red Sea. Before he was briefly a pirate captain, he was a sailor on the Batchelor's Delight which circumnavigated the globe with William Dampier.

name: Mary Read
comments: Along with Anne Bonny, one of few known female pirates. When captured, Read escaped hanging by claiming she was pregnant, but died soon after of a fever while still in prison.[26][29]

name: William Read
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean near Madagascar. He is best known for rescuing fellow pirate captains John Bowen and Thomas White.

name: Lieutenant Richards
comments: Active in the Caribbean and off the Carolinas. He is best known for sailing alongside Blackbeard (Edward Teach / Thatch).

name: John Rivers
comments: A pirate best known for leading a settlement and trading post on Madagascar.

name: Bartholomew Roberts (Black Bart)
comments: The most successful pirate of the Golden Age of Piracy, estimated to have captured more than 470 vessels.[26][29][44]

name: Philip Roche
comments: Active in the seas of northern Europe, best known for murdering the crews and captains of ships he and his men took over.

name: Tempest Rogers
comments: A pirate trader active in the Caribbean and off Madagascar. He is best known for his association with William Kidd.

name: Woodes Rogers
comments: Played a major role in the suppression of pirates in the Caribbean.[26][29][45]

name: John Russell
comments: Pirate active from Nova Scotia to the Caribbean to the African coast. He is best known for his association with Edward Low and Francis Spriggs, and for his involvement with two well-known and well-documented maroonings.

name: Jasper Seagar
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean, best known for sailing with Edward England, Olivier Levasseur, and Richard Taylor.

name: Robert Semple (Richard Sample)
comments: Was given command of a prize ship by Edward England, which was run ashore and captured off Brazil.

name: Richard Shipton
comments: Active in the Caribbean, best known for sailing alongside Edward Low and Francis Spriggs.

name: James Skyrme
comments: A Welsh pirate best known for Captaining two of Bartholomew Roberts' prize ships.

name: Francis Spriggs
comments: Along with George Lowther and Edward Low, Spriggs was primarily active in the Bay of Honduras during the early 1720s.

name: Daniel Stillwell
comments: A minor pirate in the Caribbean, best known for his association with Benjamin Hornigold.

name: Ralph Stout
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean. He is best known for rescuing fellow pirate Robert Culliford after each of them spent separate 4-year periods in Mughal Empire prisons.

name: Thomas Sutton
comments: Active off the coast of Africa. He was best known for sailing alongside Bartholomew Roberts.

name: John Swann
comments: A minor pirate in the Indian Ocean, known almost entirely for speculation about his relationship with Robert Culliford.

name: John Taylor
comments: At Reunion Island, Taylor is reputed to have captured the most valuable prize in pirate history.[26]

name: Thomas Tew
comments: Despite only going on two pirate voyages, Tew pioneered a route later known as the Pirate Round.[26][29]

name: Captain Thompson
comments: Active in the Caribbean. He is primarily known for a single incident involving grenades.

name: John Thurber
comments: Last name also Churcher, he was a pirate trader and slave trader active off Madagascar. He is best known for his role in introducing rice to America as a staple crop and export commodity.

name: Regnier Tongrelow
comments: A prolific privateer who operated out of New England. He captured a large number of ships over a short career, sending most back to New York, and was known for attacking the largest ships he could find.

name: Richard Tookerman
comments: As a pirate, smuggler, and trader active in the Caribbean and the Carolinas, he became best known for involvement with pirates Stede Bonnet and Bartholomew Roberts.

name: Rais Hamidou
comments: An Algerian privateer, later admiral whom captured several ships during his career.

name: Turn Joe
comments: Irish pirate and privateer who left English service and sailed for Spain instead as a guarda costa privateer in the Caribbean.

name: Charles Vane
comments: Disliked due to his cruelty, Vane showed little respect for the pirate code, cheating his crew out of their shares in the takings.[26][29]

name: Hendrick van Hoven
comments: A buccaneer and pirate active in the Caribbean. He was known as "the grand pirate of the West Indies."

name: John Vidal
comments: A minor Irish-American pirate briefly active near Ocracoke Inlet off North Carolina. He is best known for bringing the Farley family with him, causing Martha Farley to be one of the few women tried for piracy.

name: Thomas Wake
comments: Best known for sailing alongside Thomas Tew to join Henry Every in the Indian Ocean, hunting the Moghul treasure fleet.

name: Richard Want
comments: Active in the Indian Ocean. He is best known for sailing alongside Thomas Tew and Henry Every.

name: Brigstock Weaver
comments: He is best known for his association with fellow pirates Thomas Anstis and Bartholomew Roberts.

name: John West
comments: A minor pirate in the Caribbean, best known for his association with Benjamin Hornigold.

name: Joseph Wheeler
comments: He is best known for sailing alongside Dirk Chivers and Robert Culliford.

name: Thomas White
comments: He was only briefly a captain on his own but served under several more prominent captains such as George Booth, John Bowen, Thomas Howard, John Halsey, and Nathaniel North.

name: David Williams
comments: Welsh sailor who turned pirate after being abandoned on Madagascar. He was only briefly a Captain, and is best known for sailing under a number of more prominent pirate captains.

name: Paulsgrave Williams
comments: A pirate who sailed the Caribbean, American eastern seaboard, and off West Africa. He is best known for sailing alongside Samuel Bellamy.

name: Christopher Winter
comments: English pirate active in the Caribbean. He is best known for sailing in Spanish service and launching the career of Edward England.

name: Nicholas Woodall
comments: He is best known for his involvement with Charles Vane and Benjamin Hornigold.

name: Edward Woodman
comments: A pirate active in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

name: Richard Worley
comments: Credited as one of the first pirates to fly the skull and crossbones pirate flag.[26]

name: Emanuel Wynn
comments: Was the first pirate to fly the "skull and crossbones" Jolly Roger. His design also incorporated an hourglass below the skull.[26]

name: Charles Yeats
comments: He is best known for sailing alongside and then abandoning Charles Vane.

name: José Joaquim Almeida
comments: Portuguese Barbary corsair who fought in the Anglo-American War of 1812 and the Argentine War of Independence].

name: Peter Alston
comments: River pirate, highwayman, and counterfeiter, son of counterfeiter, Philip Alston, alias James May, who was believed to be an associate of the Samuel Mason and Micajah "Big" Harpe and Wiley "Little" Harpe.

name: Philip Alston
comments: River pirate and counterfeiter, an associate of the counterfeiter John Duff and father of river pirate, highwayman, and counterfeiter, Peter Alston.

name: François Aregnaudeau
comments: Breton who commanded a number of privateers, most notably Blonde, and Duc de Dantzig. In them he captured numerous prizes. He and Duc de Dantzig disappeared without at trace around the end of 1812. Their disappearance gave rise to an unsubstantiated gruesome ghost ship legend.

name: Louis-Michel Aury
comments: French privateer, served the Republics of Venezuela and Mexico.

name: Joseph Baker
comments: The single piratical action of his career consisted of an unsuccessful attempt to commandeer the sloop Eliza.[46]

name: Renato Beluche
comments: A known associate of the Lafitte Brothers active in the Caribbean before joining Simon Bolivar army in his fight for South American independence.

name: Hippolyte Bouchard
comments: A French and Argentine sailor who fought for Argentina, Chile and Peru.[47]

name: Luis Brion de Trox
comments: Dutch privateer, served to the Republics of Venezuela and Great Colombia.

name: Flora Burn
comments: Female pirate active mainly off the East coast of North America from 1741.

name: Cabeza de Perro
comments: Was a Spanish pirate. His physical characteristics earned him his nickname, which translates to Dog Head.

name: Henri Caesar
comments: Haitian pirate supposedly active in the Caribbean during the early 19th century. Historical existence is doubtful.

name: Eric Cobham and Maria Lindsey
comments: Cobham and his wife, Maria, were primarily active in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

name: James Copeland
comments: A leader of a gang of pirates, smugglers, and outlaws in southern Mississippi and southern Alabama, around Mobile, known as the Wages and Copeland Clan.

name: Richard Coyle
comments: He is known for a single incident involving the murder of the Captain of the ship St. John.

name: Sadie Farrell (Sadie The Goat)
comments: An Irish American New York City river pirate and the criminal leader of the Charlton Street Gang in 1869.

name: James Ford
comments: A civic leader and business owner in western Kentucky and southern Illinois, secretly, was the leader of a gang of river pirates and highwaymen, along the Ohio River, known as the "Ford's Ferry Gang."

name: Hezekiah Frith
comments: British ship owner and smuggler known as Bermuda's "gentleman privateer". Alleged to have used his business as a cover to withhold cargo sized in privateering expeditions and amass a small fortune.

name: Vincent Gambi
comments: A pirate based out of New Orleans, he was an associate of Jean Lafitte.

name: José Gaspar (Gasparilla)
comments: Spanish naval officer who turned to piracy and operated from a base in southwest Florida. Although Gaspar is a popular figure in local folklore and was the inspiration for Tampa's Gasparilla Pirate Festival, there is no evidence of his existence.[48]

name: Leoncio Prado Gutiérrez
comments: Prado a Peruvian mariner with Cuban revolutionaries seized the Spanish ship Moctezuma in the Caribbean sea at North of La Hispaniola. Renamed as Cespedes failed to liberate Cuba under Spanish rule. Realizing how the ship remained in the hands of the royalist navy, Prado ordered his men to leave and lit a barrel of gunpowder inside of the ammunition storage facilities.

name: Catherine Hagerty and Charlotte Badger
comments: Australian convicts. Among a group of convicts taken on board a shorthanded ship as crew. The convicts commandeered the ship and sailed for New Zealand. Hagerty was put ashore and died, Badger was never seen again.[49]

name: Micajah and Wiley Harpe
comments: America's first known serial killers, were Loyalists in the American Revolution, as well as, river pirates and highwaymen, who preyed on travelers along the Ohio River and the waterways of Tennessee, Kentucky, and Illinois. The Harpe Brothers were associates of Samuel Mason and Peter Alston.

name: Pugsy Hurley
comments: English-born American burglar, river pirate and underworld figure in New York City during the mid-to late 19th century. An old time thief from the old Seventh Ward, he was also a well-known waterfront thug whose criminal career lasted over two decades. He especially gained notoriety as a member of the Patsy Conroy Gang.

name: Rahmah ibn Jabir al-Jalahimah
comments: The most famous pirate in the Persian Gulf, he ruled over Qatar and Dammam for short periods and fought alongside the Wahhabis against the Al-Khalifa tribe of Bahrain.[50]

name: Bill Johnston
comments: Nicknamed "Pirate of the Thousand Islands".

name: Edward Jordan
comments: Irish rebel, fisherman and pirate of Nova Scotia.

name: Jørgen Jørgensen
comments: Danish adventurer and writer, he was captured by the British as a privateer during the Napoleonic Wars.[51]

name: Jean Lafitte
comments: French pirate (or privateer) active in the Gulf of Mexico during the early 1800s. A wanted fugitive by the United States, he later participated, during the War of 1812, in the Battle of New Orleans on the side of Andrew Jackson and the Americans. In 1822, Lafitte approached the navy of Gran Colombia and Simon Bolivar granted a commission and given a new ship, a 40-ton schooner named General Santander.

name: Pierre Lafitte
comments: French pirate, and lesser-known brother of Jean Lafitte, active mainly in the Gulf of Mexico.

name: Narciso Lopez
comments: Venezuelan adventurer, enlisted in United States about six hundred filibusters and successfully reached Cuba in May 1850 to liberate the island from Spanish Crown rule. His troops took the town of Cárdenas, carrying a flag that López had designed, which later became the banner of modern Cuba. After another failed attempt to free Cuba he was executed in Havana by the royalists in 1851.

name: Sam Hall Lord
comments: Sam Lord was one of the most famous buccaneers on the island of Barbados.

name: Kazimierz Lux
comments: The Polish Pirates of the Caribbean. After fighting against a slave rebellion in Haiti, Lux started a career of piracy – shooting and boarding an American brig was one of his more spectacular successes; the vessel was later sold for 20,000 francs in Havana.[clarification needed]

name: Gregor MacGregor
comments: A Scottish adventurer, soldier and land speculator who fought in the Venezuelan and New Granadan struggle for independence. In 1817, led an army of only 150 men in an assault on Amelia Island, Florida. After his return to Britain in 1820, he claimed to be cacique of Poyais a fictional Central American country that MacGregor had invented which, with his promotional efforts, drew investors and eventually colonists.

name: Francisco de Miranda
comments: Venezuelan militar and adventurer, who organized in 1806 two private filibustering expeditions from New York and Trinidad with the intention of liberate Venezuela under Spanish rule since XVI siecle. On April 28 of 1806 the small fleet was overtaken by Spanish warships off the coast of Venezuela. Only the Leander escaped.  The Backus and Bee were captured with all the revolutionaries. Sixty men were put on trial for piracy and Ten were sentenced to death in Puerto Cabello. The Leander and the expeditionary force regrouped on the British islands of Barbados and Trinidad, assisted by HMS Lilly. The new expedition landed at La Vela de Coro on August 3, captured the fort and raised the tricolor flag for the first time on Venezuelan soil. Before dawn the next morning the expeditionaries occupied Coro, but found no support from the city residents and Miranda returned to England.

name: Samuel Mason
comments: Initially, a Revolutionary War Patriot captain in the Ohio County, Virginia militia and an associate judge and squire in Kentucky, Mason later, ran a gang of highway robbers and waterways river pirates.

name: John A. Murrell
comments: Near-legendary bandit, known as the "Great Western Land Pirate," ran a gang of river pirates and highwaymen along the Mississippi River.

name: Robert Surcouf
comments: French privateer and slave trader who operated in the Indian Ocean between 1789 and 1801, and again from 1807 to 1808, capturing over 40 prizes, while amassing a large fortune as a ship-owner, both from privateering and from commerce.

name: Rachel Wall
comments: Rachel and her husband George Wall were active off the New Hampshire coast until George and the crew were washed out to sea. She was hanged in Boston on 8 October 1789.

name: William Walker
comments: American lawyer, journalist and adventurer, who organized several private military expeditions into Latin America, with the intention of establishing English-speaking colonies under his personal control. Walker became president of the Republic of Nicaragua in 1856 and ruled until 1857, when he was defeated by a coalition of Central American armies. He was executed in Trujillo by the government of Honduras in 1860.

name: Alexander White
comments: Hanged for piracy in Cambridge, Massachusetts in November 1784.[citation needed]

name: Dominique You
comments: Acquired a reputation for daring as a pirate. Retired to become a politician in New Orleans.

name: Mansel Alcantra (Alcantara)
comments: In 1829, he captured the Topaz off St. Helena and had the entire crew murdered.

name: Roberto Cofresí
comments: Considered the "last of the [successful] West India pirates", Cofresí avoided capture by the navies of six nations for years and became the final target of the West Indies Anti-Piracy Operations.[52] After being captured by the Puerto Rican militia, he claimed to have a stash of 4,000 pieces of eight hidden, which he tried to use as a bribe.[53]

name: Diabolito (Little Devil)
comments: Cuban-born pirate active in the Caribbean during the early 19th century. He was one of the first pirates to be hunted down by Commodore David Porter and the Mosquito Fleet during the early 1820s.

name: Charles Gibbs
comments: One of the last pirates active in the Caribbean, and one of the last people executed for piracy by the United States.[54]

name: "Don" Pedro Gilbert
comments: Took part in the last recorded incident of piracy in Atlantic waters.[55][56]

name: Benito de Soto
comments: The most notorious of the last generation to attack shipping on the Atlantic Ocean.

name: Tuanku Abbas
comments: The brother of a rajah of Achin, known for his sponsoring and leading of pirate raids.

name: Eli Boggs
comments: Pirate who sailed in Chinese junk for smuggling.

name: Cheng I
comments: A pirate on the Chinese coast in the 18h and 19th centuries.

name: Cheung Po Tsai
comments: Active along the Guangdong coast and is said to have commanded a fleet of 600 junks.

name: Ching Shih
comments: A prominent female pirate in late Qing China.

name: Chui A-poo
comments: Based in Bias Bay east of Hong Kong, Chui preyed on merchant ships in the South China Sea until his fleet was defeated by the Royal Navy in 1849.[57]

name: Abdulla al-Hadj
comments: English pirate primarily known for his activity in the South China Sea[58]

name: Shap Ng-tsai
comments: Commanded around 70 junks in the South China Sea before retiring and accepting a pardon from the Chinese government.

name: Nathaniel Gordon
comments: The first and only American slave trader to be tried, convicted, and executed "for being engaged in the Slave Trade" in accordance with the Piracy Law of 1820.[59]

name: Bully Hayes
comments: The Pirate of the South Sea, was a notorious blackbirder in the South Pacific, and was described as "the last of the Buccaneers".

name: Albert W. Hicks
comments: New York waterfront thug who killed the 3-man crew of an oyster sloop after being shanghaied. He was the last man hung for piracy in the United States.

name: James "Shanghai" Kelly
comments: A legendary figure in San Francisco history who owned several boarding houses and saloons, Kelly was renowned for his ability to supply men to understaffed ships. He was reported to have shanghaied 100 men for three ships in a single evening, by hosting a free booze cruise to celebrate his "birthday", then serving opium-laced whiskey to knock out his guests.[60]

name: Joseph "Bunko" Kelly
comments: The "King of the Crimps" in Portland, Oregon, he shanghaiied over 2,000 men in all. In 1893, he delivered 20+ men who had mistakenly consumed embalming fluid from the open cellar of a mortuary. The ship sailed off before the captain realized most of the men were dead.[61]

name: Pedro Ñancupel
comments: A Pilgerodendron lumberjack turned pirate who was active in Guaitecas Archipelago and other archipelagoes of Patagonia in the 1870s and 1880s. Ñancupel was captured in Melinka in 1886 and bought into justice in Ancud the same year. After escaping from detainment in Ancud he was captured once again and executed by firing squad on November 11, 1888. He was said at the time to have killed 99 persons.

name: Ben Pease
comments: A New England sea captain who kidnapped Pacific Islanders aboard the Pioneer, providing labor for the plantations of Fiji. When Bully Hayes was arrested for piracy in Samoa,  Pease helped him to escape.  When next the Pioneer returned to port,  Hayes was at the helm, and was rumored to have killed Pease during a fight.

name: Asad 'Booyah' Abdulahi
comments: Somali pirate boss, active in capturing ships in the Gulf of Aden and Indian Ocean for ransoms.[62]

name: Román Delgado Chalbaud
comments: On 11 August 1929 Delgado Chalbaud led the steamship Falke, (renamed General Anzoátegui for the occasion) into Cumaná  in a failed attempt to overthrow Venezuelan dictator Juan Vicente Gomez. After landing in Cumana the expeditionary force of 250–300 men soon ran into problems by government troops.
